answers.answer: If they are checking her urine then they should also be checking it for sugar and ketones. Both of these are indicators of diabetes. (Ketones can also be present if one is starved or vomitting). The odor could be because of dehydration (although she is drinking alot) or because of infection.

Check out the diabetes community, too.  There are many posters there who have lots of information about diabetes.If you are concerned, she should be taken to the ped and a simple blood sugar can be checked.  Strong smelling urine can be from an infection or other things.

Kinda gross, but the way my neighbor found out that her daughter had juvenile diabetes was that her daughter went pee in the toilet in the middle of the night.  When the mom got up in the morning and went in to the bathroom, the entire toilet seat and down in to the bowl was covered with ants.  They were attracted to the sweet smell and sugar in her urine.

question: Ok, so I asked about my 2 yr old on here earlier. I had one other question though. I am not at all familiar with diabetes. All I know it that my grandpa had it bad and so lately when my daughter started drinking tons of fluids throughout the day as if she was always thirsty and acting tired, well my Mother began to quesiton diabetes. Can a strong smell of urine be a sign of diabetes? She ALWAYS has a very strong smell/odor and has told me many of times that it hurts down there, but we had the doctor run tests on her for a UTI or Bladder Infection and all came back negative/normal. So I was wondering if there was any relation to that? Anyone out there have a child with diabetes?
title: Another question related to diabetes in kids
